input_args.examples: {'document_id': ['0000690', '0000690', '0000684', '0000684'], 'document_source': ['GHR', 'GHR', 'GHR', 'GHR'], 'document_url': ['https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/multiple-familial-trichoepithelioma', 'https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/multiple-familial-trichoepithelioma', 'https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/muenke-syndrome', 'https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/condition/muenke-syndrome'], 'category': [None, None, None, None], 'umls_cui': ['C1275122', 'C1275122', 'C1864436', 'C1864436'], 'umls_semantic_types': ['T191', 'T191', 'T019|T047', 'T019|T047'], 'umls_semantic_group': ['Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders'], 'synonyms': ['Brooke-Fordyce trichoepitheliomas|EAC|epithelioma adenoides cysticum of Brooke|familial multiple trichoepitheliomata|hereditary multiple benign cystic epithelioma|MFT', 'Brooke-Fordyce trichoepitheliomas|EAC|epithelioma adenoides cysticum of Brooke|familial multiple trichoepitheliomata|hereditary multiple benign cystic epithelioma|MFT', 'FGFR3-associated coronal synostosis|Muenke nonsyndromic coronal craniosynostosis', 'FGFR3-associated coronal synostosis|Muenke nonsyndromic coronal craniosynostosis'], 'question_id': ['0000690-4', '0000690-5', '0000684-1', '0000684-2'], 'question_focus': ['multiple familial trichoepithelioma', 'multiple familial trichoepithelioma', 'Muenke syndrome', 'Muenke syndrome'], 'question_type': ['inheritance', 'treatment', 'information', 'frequency'], 'question': ['Is multiple familial trichoepithelioma inherited ?', 'What are the treatments for multiple familial trichoepithelioma ?', 'What is (are) Muenke syndrome ?', 'How many people are affected by Muenke syndrome ?'], 'answer': ['Susceptibility to multiple familial trichoepithelioma has an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, which means one copy of the altered gene in each cell increases the risk of developing this condition. However, a second, non-inherited mutation is required for development of skin appendage tumors in this disorder.', 'These resources address the diagnosis or management of multiple familial trichoepithelioma:  - Genetic Testing Registry: Familial multiple trichoepitheliomata  - Genetic Testing Registry: Trichoepithelioma multiple familial 2   These resources from MedlinePlus offer information about the diagnosis and management of various health conditions:  - Diagnostic Tests  - Drug Therapy  - Surgery and Rehabilitation  - Genetic Counseling   - Palliative Care', 'Muenke syndrome is a condition characterized by the premature closure of certain bones of the skull (craniosynostosis) during development, which affects the shape of the head and face.  Many people with this disorder have a premature fusion of skull bones along the coronal suture, the growth line which goes over the head from ear to ear. Other parts of the skull may be malformed as well. These changes can result in an abnormally shaped head, wide-set eyes, and flattened cheekbones. About 5 percent of affected individuals have an enlarged head (macrocephaly). People with Muenke syndrome may also have mild abnormalities of the hands or feet, and hearing loss has been observed in some cases. Most people with this condition have normal intellect, but developmental delay and learning disabilities are possible.  The signs and symptoms of Muenke syndrome vary among affected people, and some findings overlap with those seen in other craniosynostosis syndromes. Between 6 percent and 7 percent of people with the gene mutation associated with Muenke syndrome do not have any of the characteristic features of the disorder.', 'Muenke syndrome occurs in about 1 in 30,000 newborns. This condition accounts for an estimated 8 percent of all cases of craniosynostosis.']}
